text: `rand()` by default only gives you numbers in the range `[0, 1)`.  you need to transform it to get numbers in a different range

text:
There's also Distributions.jl which have a Uniform distribution defined

rand(Uniform(5, 7), 100)

which produces a 100-element array with uniformly random numbers from 5 to 7

But I don't know if there's any significant overhead to that compared to doing it yourself. In case you're producing lots of random numbers repeatedly

text:
Also yes it can be confusing at first, and I think you're right and its understandable how confusing it can be at first. `rand` indeed does do a lot of things depending on what the input is.

e.g. rand() gives you a single random scalar. rand(100) gives you a 100 random numbers. rand([1, 2, 3, 4]) selects uniformly from the elements of the matrix, etc. etc. 

I think it's fairly common in Julia where you get different behaviors based on the different arguments you put into something (e.g. Multiple Dispatch)
